doc.title: CONJscan - T4SSscan

description.text: Search for relaxases and key components of type IV secretion systems in proteomes using an HMM profiles database.

doc.authors: Guglielmini, J., L. Quintais, M. P. Garcillán-Barcia, F. de la Cruz, E. P. C. Rocha
doc.reference: Guglielmini, J., L. Quintais, M. P. Garcillán-Barcia, F. de la Cruz, E. P. C. Rocha (2011). The Repertoire of ICE in Prokaryotes Underscores the Unity, Diversity, and Ubiquity of Conjugation. PLoS Genet., 7(8): e1002222.
Eddy, S. R. (2011). Accelerated Profile HMM Searches. PLoS Comput. Biol., 7(10): e1002195.
Eddy, S. R. (2008). A probabilistic model of local sequence alignment that simplifies statistical significance estimation. PLoS Comput. Biol., 4:e1000069.
Eddy, S. R. (1998). Profile hidden Markov models. Bioinformatics, 14:755-763.

div.p: Scans a set of protein sequences for type IV secretion systems and relaxases using HMM profiles. See Guglielmini et al. (2011) for our criteria to class loci on the basis of this output. Except when it makes sense biologically, we recommend ignoring the hits covering less than half of the profile or with c-Evalue < 0.01.

The output consists of three sections: a ranked list of the best scoring HMMs, a list of the best scoring domains in order of their occurrence in the sequence, and alignments for all the best scoring domains. A sequence score may be higher than a domain score for the same sequence if there is more than one domain in the sequence; the sequence score takes into account all the domains. All sequences scoring above the -E and -T cutoffs are shown in the first list, then every domain found in this list is shown in the second list of domain hits. If desired, E-value and score thresholds may also be applied to the domain list using the --domE and --domT options.
We recommend ignoring the hits covering less than half of the profile or with c-Evalue < 0.01. See this page.

xhtml:div.label:
E_value cutoff (-E)?
In the per-target output, report target profiles with an E-value of <= value. The default is 10.0, meaning that on average, about 10 false positives will be reported per query, so you can see the top of the 'noise' and decide for yourself if it's really noise.

Bit score cutoff (-T)?
Instead of thresholding per-profile output on E-value, instead report target profiles with a bit score of >= value.

E-value cutoff for the per-domain ranked hit list (--domE)?
In the per-domain output, for target profiles that have already satisfied the perprofile reporting threshold, report individual domains with a conditional E-value of <= value. The default is 10.0. A 'conditional' E-value means the expected number of additional false positive domains in the smaller search space of those comparisons that already satisfied the per-profile reporting threshold (and thus must have at least one homologous domain already).

Bit score cutoff for the per-domain ranked hit list (--domT)?
Instead of thresholding per-domain output on E-value, instead report domains with a bit score of >= value.

xhtml:div.xhtml:div: 'Inclusion' thresholds are stricter than reporting thresholds. Inclusion thresholds control which hits are considered to be reliable enough to be included in an output alignment or a subsequent search round. In hmmscan, which does not have any alignment output nor any iterative search steps, inclusion thresholds have little effect. They only affect what domains get marked as significant ('!') or questionable ('?') in domain output.

xhtml:div.label:
Include sequences lower than this E-value threshold (--incE)?
Use an E-value of <= value as the per-target inclusion threshold. The default is 0.01, meaning that on average, about 1 false positive would be expected in every 100 searches with different query sequences.

Include domains lower than this E-value threshold (--incdomE)?
Use a conditional E-value of <= value as the per-domain inclusion threshold, in targets that have already satisfied the overall per-target inclusion threshold. The default is 0.01.

Include sequences upper than this score threshold (--incT)?
Instead of using E-values for setting the inclusion threshold, instead use a bit score of >= the value as the per-target inclusion threshold. It would be unusual to use bit score thresholds with hmmscan, because you don't expect a single score threshold to work for different profiles; different profiles have slightly different expected score distributions.

Include domans upper than this score threshold (--incdomT)?
Instead of using E-values, instead use a bit score of >= value as the per-domain inclusion threshold. As with --incT above, it would be unusual to use a single bit score threshold in hmmscan.

Options for model-specific thresholding?
No profile use profile's GA gathering cutoffs (cut_ga) use profile's NC noise cutoffs (cut_nc) use profile's TC trusted cutoffs (cut_tc)
Curated profile databases may define specific bit score thresholds for each profile, superseding any thresholding based on statistical significance alone. To use these options, the profile must contain the appropriate (GA, TC, and/or NC) optional score threshold annotation; this is picked up by hmmbuild from Stockholm format alignment files. Each thresholding option has two scores: the per-sequence threshold x1 value and the per-domain threshold x2 value. These act as if -T x1 --incT x1 --domT x2 --incdomT x2 has been applied specifically using each model's curated thresholds.
cut ga: Use the GA (gathering) bit scores in the model to set per-sequence (GA1) and per-domain (GA2) reporting and inclusion thresholds. GA thresholds are generally considered to be the reliable curated thresholds defining family membership; for example, in Pfam, these thresholds define what gets included in Pfam Full alignments based on searches with Pfam Seed models.
cut_nc: Use the NC (noise cutoff) bit score thresholds in the model to set per-sequence (NC1) and per-domain (NC2) reporting and inclusion thresholds. NC thresholds are generally considered to be the score of the highest-scoring known false positive.
cut_tc: Use the NC (trusted cutoff) bit score thresholds in the model to set per-sequence (TC1) and per-domain (TC2) reporting and inclusion thresholds. TC thresholds are generally considered to be the score of the lowest-scoring known true positive that is above all known false positives.

xhtml:div.xhtml:div: HMMER3 searches are accelerated in a three-step filter pipeline: the MSV filter, the Viterbi filter, and the Forward filter. The first filter is the fastest and most approximate; the last is the full Forward scoring algorithm. There is also a 'bias filter' step between MSV and Viterbi. Targets that pass all the steps in the acceleration pipeline are then subjected to 'postprocessing' -- domain identification and scoring using the Forward/Backward algorithm. Changing filter thresholds only removes or includes targets from consideration; changing filter thresholds does not alter bit scores, E-values, or alignments, all of which are determined solely in 'postprocessing'.

xhtml:div.label:
Turn all heuristic filters off (less speed, more power) (--max)?
Yes No
Turn off all filters, including the bias filter, and run full Forward/Backward postprocessing on every target. This increases sensitivity somewhat, at a large cost in speed.

Stage 1 (MSV) threshold?
Set the P-value threshold for the MSV filter step. The default is 0.02, meaning that roughly 2% of the highest scoring nonhomologous targets are expected to pass the filter.

Stage 1 (Vit) threshold?
Set the P-value threshold for the Viterbi filter step. The default is 0.001.

Stage 1 (Fwd) threshold?
Set the P-value threshold for the Forward filter step. The default is 1e-5.

Turn off composition bias filter (--nobias)?
Yes No
Turn off the bias filter. This increases sensitivity somewhat, but can come at a high cost in speed, especially if the query has biased residue composition (such as a repetitive sequence region, or if it is a membrane protein with large regions of hydrophobicity). Without the bias filter, too many sequences may pass the filter with biased queries, leading to slower than expected performance as the computationally intensive Forward/Backward algorithms shoulder an abnormally heavy load.

Turn off biased composition score corrections (--nonull2)?
Yes No
Turn off the 'null2' score corrections for biased composition.

Control of E_value calculation (-Z)?
Assert that the total number of targets in your searches is the value, for the purposes of per-sequence E-value calculations, rather than the actual number of targets seen.

Set Z score of significant sequences, for domain E-value calculation (--domZ)?
Assert that the total number of targets in your searches is the value, for the purposes of per-domain conditional E-value calculations, rather than the number of targets that passed the reporting thresholds.

Set RNG seed number (--seed)?
Set the random number seed to value. Some steps in postprocessing require Monte Carlo simulation. The default is to use a fixed seed (42), so that results are exactly reproducible. Any other positive integer will give different (but also reproducible) results. A choice of 0 uses a 'randomly chosen' seed.
Name of the sequence(s) file (-o)

File name of parseable table of per-sequence hits (--tblout)?
Save a simple tabular (space-delimited) file summarizing the 'per-target' output, with one data line per homologous target model found

File name of parseable table of per-domain hits (--domtblout)?
Save a simple tabular (space-delimited) file summarizing the 'per-domain' output, with one data line per homologous domain detected in a query sequence for each homologous model.

Prefer accessions over names in output?
Yes No
Use accessions instead of names in the main output, where available for profiles and/or sequences

Don't output alignments, so output is smaller?
Yes No
Omit the alignment section from the main output. This can greatly reduce the output volume.

Unlimit ASCII text output line width (--notextw)?
Yes No
Unlimit the length of each line in the main output. The default is a limit of 120 characters per line, which helps in displaying the output cleanly on terminals and in editors, but can truncate target profile description lines.

Set max width of ASCII text output lines (--textw)?
Set the main output's line length limit to value> characters per line. The default is 120.

xhtml:div.xhtml:div: In the per-target output, report target profiles with an E-value of <= value. The default is 10.0, meaning that on average, about 10 false positives will be reported per query, so you can see the top of the 'noise' and decide for yourself if it's really noise.
Instead of thresholding per-profile output on E-value, instead report target profiles with a bit score of >= value.

In the per-domain output, for target profiles that have already satisfied the perprofile reporting threshold, report individual domains with a conditional E-value of <= value. The default is 10.0. A 'conditional' E-value means the expected number of additional false positive domains in the smaller search space of those comparisons that already satisfied the per-profile reporting threshold (and thus must have at least one homologous domain already).
Instead of thresholding per-domain output on E-value, instead report domains with a bit score of >= value.

Use an E-value of <= value as the per-target inclusion threshold. The default is 0.01, meaning that on average, about 1 false positive would be expected in every 100 searches with different query sequences.
Use a conditional E-value of <= value as the per-domain inclusion threshold, in targets that have already satisfied the overall per-target inclusion threshold. The default is 0.01.

Instead of using E-values for setting the inclusion threshold, instead use a bit score of >= the value as the per-target inclusion threshold. It would be unusual to use bit score thresholds with hmmscan, because you don't expect a single score threshold to work for different profiles; different profiles have slightly different expected score distributions.
Instead of using E-values, instead use a bit score of >= value as the per-domain inclusion threshold. As with --incT above, it would be unusual to use a single bit score threshold in hmmscan.

Curated profile databases may define specific bit score thresholds for each profile, superseding any thresholding based on statistical significance alone. To use these options, the profile must contain the appropriate (GA, TC, and/or NC) optional score threshold annotation; this is picked up by hmmbuild from Stockholm format alignment files. Each thresholding option has two scores: the per-sequence threshold x1 value and the per-domain threshold x2 value. These act as if -T x1 --incT x1 --domT x2 --incdomT x2 has been applied specifically using each model's curated thresholds.

cut ga: Use the GA (gathering) bit scores in the model to set per-sequence (GA1) and per-domain (GA2) reporting and inclusion thresholds. GA thresholds are generally considered to be the reliable curated thresholds defining family membership; for example, in Pfam, these thresholds define what gets included in Pfam Full alignments based on searches with Pfam Seed models.

cut_nc: Use the NC (noise cutoff) bit score thresholds in the model to set per-sequence (NC1) and per-domain (NC2) reporting and inclusion thresholds. NC thresholds are generally considered to be the score of the highest-scoring known false positive.

cut_tc: Use the NC (trusted cutoff) bit score thresholds in the model to set per-sequence (TC1) and per-domain (TC2) reporting and inclusion thresholds. TC thresholds are generally considered to be the score of the lowest-scoring known true positive that is above all known false positives.
Turn off all filters, including the bias filter, and run full Forward/Backward postprocessing on every target. This increases sensitivity somewhat, at a large cost in speed.
Set the P-value threshold for the MSV filter step. The default is 0.02, meaning that roughly 2% of the highest scoring nonhomologous targets are expected to pass the filter.
Set the P-value threshold for the Viterbi filter step. The default is 0.001.
Set the P-value threshold for the Forward filter step. The default is 1e-5.

Turn off the bias filter. This increases sensitivity somewhat, but can come at a high cost in speed, especially if the query has biased residue composition (such as a repetitive sequence region, or if it is a membrane protein with large regions of hydrophobicity). Without the bias filter, too many sequences may pass the filter with biased queries, leading to slower than expected performance as the computationally intensive Forward/Backward algorithms shoulder an abnormally heavy load.
Turn off the 'null2' score corrections for biased composition.
Assert that the total number of targets in your searches is the value, for the purposes of per-sequence E-value calculations, rather than the actual number of targets seen.

Assert that the total number of targets in your searches is the value, for the purposes of per-domain conditional E-value calculations, rather than the number of targets that passed the reporting thresholds.

Set the random number seed to value. Some steps in postprocessing require Monte Carlo simulation. The default is to use a fixed seed (42), so that results are exactly reproducible. Any other positive integer will give different (but also reproducible) results. A choice of 0 uses a 'randomly chosen' seed.
Save a simple tabular (space-delimited) file summarizing the 'per-target' output, with one data line per homologous target model found
Save a simple tabular (space-delimited) file summarizing the 'per-domain' output, with one data line per homologous domain detected in a query sequence for each homologous model.
Use accessions instead of names in the main output, where available for profiles and/or sequences
Omit the alignment section from the main output. This can greatly reduce the output volume.

Unlimit the length of each line in the main output. The default is a limit of 120 characters per line, which helps in displaying the output cleanly on terminals and in editors, but can truncate target profile description lines.
Set the main output's line length limit to value> characters per line. The default is 120.

parameter.name: prog_desc
parameter.prompt: Program description

div.p: Scans a set of protein sequences for type IV secretion systems and relaxases using HMM profiles. See Guglielmini et al. (2011) for our criteria to class loci on the basis of this output. Except when it makes sense biologically, we recommend ignoring the hits covering less than half of the profile or with c-Evalue < 0.01.

The output consists of three sections: a ranked list of the best scoring HMMs, a list of the best scoring domains in order of their occurrence in the sequence, and alignments for all the best scoring domains. A sequence score may be higher than a domain score for the same sequence if there is more than one domain in the sequence; the sequence score takes into account all the domains. All sequences scoring above the -E and -T cutoffs are shown in the first list, then every domain found in this list is shown in the second list of domain hits. If desired, E-value and score thresholds may also be applied to the domain list using the --domE and --domT options.
We recommend ignoring the hits covering less than half of the profile or with c-Evalue < 0.01. See this page.

parameter.name: seqfile
parameter.prompt: Sequence file

parameter.name: HMMDB
parameter.prompt: HMM database

parameter.name: E_value_cutoff
parameter.prompt: E_value cutoff (-E)

precond.code: not defined $Bit_cutoff and $model_specific ne '--cut_ga' and $model_specific ne '--cut_nc'
Bit_cutoff is None and model_specific != '--cut_ga' and model_specific != '--cut_nc'

format.code: ( "" , " -E " + str(value) )[ value is not None and value != vdef]

comment.text: In the per-target output, report target profiles with an E-value of <= value. The default is 10.0, meaning that on average, about 10 false positives will be reported per query, so you can see the top of the 'noise' and decide for yourself if it's really noise.

parameter.prompt: E-value cutoff for the per-domain ranked hit list (--domE)

domT is None and model_specific != '--cut_ga' and model_specific != '--cut_nc'

format.code: ( "" , " --domE " + str(value) )[ value is not None and value !=vdef ]

The default is 10.0. A 'conditional' E-value means the expected number of additional false positive domains in the smaller search space of those comparisons that already satisfied the per-profile reporting threshold (and thus must have at least one homologous domain already).

Instead of thresholding per-domain output on E-value, instead report domains with a bit score of >= value.

In hmmscan, which does not have any alignment output nor any iterative search steps, inclusion thresholds have little effect. parameter.prompt: Include sequences lower than this E-value threshold (--incE)

format.code: ( "" , " --incE " + str(value) )[ value is not None and value != vdef]

comment.text: Use an E-value of <= value as the per-target inclusion threshold. The default is 0.01, meaning that on average, about 1 false positive would be expected in every 100 searches with different query sequences.

parameter.name: model_specific
parameter.prompt: Options for model-specific thresholding

precond.code: not defined $Bit_cutoff and not $E_value_cutoff == 10.0 and not defined $incdomT and $incdomE == 0.01
not Bit_cutoff and E_value_cutoff == 10.0 and incdomT is None and incdomE == 0.01

format.code: ( "" , " " + str(value) )[ value is not None and value != vdef]

comment.text: Curated profile databases may define specific bit score thresholds for each profile, superseding any thresholding based on statistical significance alone. To use these options, the profile must contain the appropriate (GA, TC, and/or NC) optional score threshold annotation; this is picked up by hmmbuild from Stockholm format alignment files. Each thresholding option has two scores: the per-sequence threshold x1 value and the per-domain threshold x2 value. These act as if -T x1 --incT x1 --domT x2 --incdomT x2 has been applied specifically using each model's curated thresholds.

cut ga: Use the GA (gathering) bit scores in the model to set per-sequence (GA1) and per-domain (GA2) reporting and inclusion thresholds. GA thresholds are generally considered to be the reliable curated thresholds defining family membership; for example, in Pfam, these thresholds define what gets included in Pfam Full alignments based on searches with Pfam Seed models.

cut_nc: Use the NC (noise cutoff) bit score thresholds in the model to set per-sequence (NC1) and per-domain (NC2) reporting and inclusion thresholds. NC thresholds are generally considered to be the score of the highest-scoring known false positive.

cut_tc: Use the NC (trusted cutoff) bit score thresholds in the model to set per-sequence (TC1) and per-domain (TC2) reporting and inclusion thresholds. TC thresholds are generally considered to be the score of the lowest-scoring known true positive that is above all known false positives.

interface.label:
Options for model-specific thresholding?
No profile use profile's GA gathering cutoffs (cut_ga) use profile's NC noise cutoffs (cut_nc) use profile's TC trusted cutoffs (cut_tc)

Each thresholding option has two scores: the per-sequence threshold x1 value and the per-domain threshold x2 value. These act as if -T x1 --incT x1 --domT x2 --incdomT x2 has been applied specifically using each model's curated thresholds.

cut_tc: Use the NC (trusted cutoff) bit score thresholds in the model to set per-sequence (TC1) and per-domain (TC2) reporting and inclusion thresholds. TC thresholds are generally considered to be the score of the lowest-scoring known true positive that is above all known false positives.

The first filter is the fastest and most approximate; the last is the full Forward scoring algorithm. There is also a 'bias filter' step between MSV and Viterbi. parameter.name: max
parameter.prompt: Turn all heuristic filters off (less speed, more power) (--max)

comment.text: Turn off all filters, including the bias filter, and run full Forward/Backward postprocessing on every target. This increases sensitivity somewhat, at a large cost in speed.

interface.label:
Turn all heuristic filters off (less speed, more power) (--max)?
Yes No
Turn off all filters, including the bias filter, and run full Forward/Backward postprocessing on every target. This increases sensitivity somewhat, at a large cost in speed.

parameter.name: F1
parameter.prompt: Stage 1 (MSV) threshold

format.code: ( "" , " --F1 " + str(value) )[ value is not None and value != vdef]

comment.text: Set the P-value threshold for the MSV filter step. The default is 0.02, meaning that roughly 2% of the highest scoring nonhomologous targets are expected to pass the filter.

interface.label:
Stage 1 (Vit) threshold?
Set the P-value threshold for the Viterbi filter step. The default is 0.001.

xhtml:div.xhtml:div: Set the P-value threshold for the Viterbi filter step. The default is 0.001.

parameter.name: F3
parameter.prompt: Stage 1 (Fwd) threshold

format.code: ( "" , " --F3 " + str(value) )[ value is not None and value != vdef]

comment.text: Set the P-value threshold for the Forward filter step. The default is 1e-5.

interface.label:
Stage 1 (Fwd) threshold?
Set the P-value threshold for the Forward filter step. The default is 1e-5.

xhtml:div.xhtml:div: Set the P-value threshold for the Forward filter step. The default is 1e-5.

parameter.name: nobias
parameter.prompt: Turn off composition bias filter (--nobias)

comment.text: Turn off the bias filter. This increases sensitivity somewhat, but can come at a high cost in speed, especially if the query has biased residue composition (such as a repetitive sequence region, or if it is a membrane protein with large regions of hydrophobicity). Without the bias filter, too many sequences may pass the filter with biased queries, leading to slower than expected performance as the computationally intensive Forward/Backward algorithms shoulder an abnormally heavy load.

interface.label:
Turn off composition bias filter (--nobias)?
Yes No
Turn off the bias filter. This increases sensitivity somewhat, but can come at a high cost in speed, especially if the query has biased residue composition (such as a repetitive sequence region, or if it is a membrane protein with large regions of hydrophobicity). Without the bias filter, too many sequences may pass the filter with biased queries, leading to slower than expected performance as the computationally intensive Forward/Backward algorithms shoulder an abnormally heavy load.

xhtml:div.xhtml:div: Turn off the bias filter. This increases sensitivity somewhat, but can come at a high cost in speed, especially if the query has biased residue composition (such as a repetitive sequence region, or if it is a membrane protein with large regions of hydrophobicity). Without the bias filter, too many sequences may pass the filter with biased queries, leading to slower than expected performance as the computationally intensive Forward/Backward algorithms shoulder an abnormally heavy load.

parameter.name: nonull2
parameter.prompt: Turn off biased composition score corrections (--nonull2)

comment.text: Turn off the 'null2' score corrections for biased composition.

interface.label:
Turn off biased composition score corrections (--nonull2)?
Yes No
Turn off the 'null2' score corrections for biased composition.

xhtml:div.xhtml:div: Turn off the 'null2' score corrections for biased composition.

parameter.name: E_value_calculation
parameter.prompt: Control of E_value calculation (-Z)

comment.text: Assert that the total number of targets in your searches is the value, for the purposes of per-sequence E-value calculations, rather than the actual number of targets seen.

interface.label:
Control of E_value calculation (-Z)?
Assert that the total number of targets in your searches is the value, for the purposes of per-sequence E-value calculations, rather than the actual number of targets seen.

xhtml:div.xhtml:div: Assert that the total number of targets in your searches is the value, for the purposes of per-sequence E-value calculations, rather than the actual number of targets seen.

parameter.name: domZ
parameter.prompt: Set Z score of significant sequences, for domain E-value calculation (--domZ)

comment.text: Assert that the total number of targets in your searches is the value, for the purposes of per-domain conditional E-value calculations, rather than the number of targets that passed the reporting thresholds.

interface.label:
Set Z score of significant sequences, for domain E-value calculation (--domZ)?
Assert that the total number of targets in your searches is the value, for the purposes of per-domain conditional E-value calculations, rather than the number of targets that passed the reporting thresholds.

xhtml:div.xhtml:div: Assert that the total number of targets in your searches is the value, for the purposes of per-domain conditional E-value calculations, rather than the number of targets that passed the reporting thresholds.

parameter.name: seed
parameter.prompt: Set RNG seed number (--seed)

format.code: ( "" , " --seed " + str(value) )[ value is not None and value !=vdef ]

comment.text: Set the random number seed to value. Some steps in postprocessing require Monte Carlo simulation. The default is to use a fixed seed (42), so that results are exactly reproducible. Any other positive integer will give different (but also reproducible) results. A choice of 0 uses a 'randomly chosen' seed.

interface.label:
Set RNG seed number (--seed)?
Set the random number seed to value. Some steps in postprocessing require Monte Carlo simulation. The default is to use a fixed seed (42), so that results are exactly reproducible. Any other positive integer will give different (but also reproducible) results. A choice of 0 uses a 'randomly chosen' seed.

xhtml:div.xhtml:div: Set the random number seed to value. Some steps in postprocessing require Monte Carlo simulation. The default is to use a fixed seed (42), so that results are exactly reproducible. Any other positive integer will give different (but also reproducible) results. A choice of 0 uses a 'randomly chosen' seed.

parameter.name: outfile_name
parameter.prompt: Name of the sequence(s) file (-o)

interface.label: Name of the sequence(s) file (-o)

parameter.name: output_file_name
parameter.prompt: Output file

parameter.name: perseqfile_name
parameter.prompt: File name of parseable table of per-sequence hits (--tblout)

comment.text: Save a simple tabular (space-delimited) file summarizing the 'per-target' output, with one data line per homologous target model found

interface.label:
File name of parseable table of per-sequence hits (--tblout)?
Save a simple tabular (space-delimited) file summarizing the 'per-target' output, with one data line per homologous target model found

xhtml:div.xhtml:div: Save a simple tabular (space-delimited) file summarizing the 'per-target' output, with one data line per homologous target model found

parameter.name: output_perseqfile_name
parameter.prompt: Output parseable table of per-sequence hits

parameter.name: perdomfile_name
parameter.prompt: File name of parseable table of per-domain hits (--domtblout)

comment.text: Save a simple tabular (space-delimited) file summarizing the 'per-domain' output, with one data line per homologous domain detected in a query sequence for each homologous model.

interface.label:
File name of parseable table of per-domain hits (--domtblout)?
Save a simple tabular (space-delimited) file summarizing the 'per-domain' output, with one data line per homologous domain detected in a query sequence for each homologous model.

xhtml:div.xhtml:div: Save a simple tabular (space-delimited) file summarizing the 'per-domain' output, with one data line per homologous domain detected in a query sequence for each homologous model.

parameter.name: acc
parameter.prompt: Prefer accessions over names in output

comment.text: Use accessions instead of names in the main output, where available for profiles and/or sequences

interface.label:
Prefer accessions over names in output?
Yes No
Use accessions instead of names in the main output, where available for profiles and/or sequences

xhtml:div.xhtml:div: Use accessions instead of names in the main output, where available for profiles and/or sequences

parameter.name: noali
parameter.prompt: Don't output alignments, so output is smaller

comment.text: Omit the alignment section from the main output. This can greatly reduce the output volume.

interface.label:
Don't output alignments, so output is smaller?
Yes No
Omit the alignment section from the main output. This can greatly reduce the output volume.

xhtml:div.xhtml:div: Omit the alignment section from the main output. This can greatly reduce the output volume.

parameter.name: notextw
parameter.prompt: Unlimit ASCII text output line width (--notextw)

comment.text: Unlimit the length of each line in the main output. The default is a limit of 120 characters per line, which helps in displaying the output cleanly on terminals and in editors, but can truncate target profile description lines.

interface.label:
Unlimit ASCII text output line width (--notextw)?
Yes No
Unlimit the length of each line in the main output. The default is a limit of 120 characters per line, which helps in displaying the output cleanly on terminals and in editors, but can truncate target profile description lines.

xhtml:div.xhtml:div: Unlimit the length of each line in the main output. The default is a limit of 120 characters per line, which helps in displaying the output cleanly on terminals and in editors, but can truncate target profile description lines.

parameter.name: textw
parameter.prompt: Set max width of ASCII text output lines (--textw)

format.code: ( "" , " --textw " + str(value) )[ value is not None and value !=vdef ]

comment.text: Set the main output's line length limit to value> characters per line. The default is 120.

interface.label:
Set max width of ASCII text output lines (--textw)?
Set the main output's line length limit to value> characters per line. The default is 120.

xhtml:div.xhtml:div: Set the main output's line length limit to value> characters per line. The default is 120.
